data.title: My FAVE TAKE OUT....hands down!
data.text: I have been eating here for years and continue to order take on a weekly basis. Authentic food, family owned and operated, they will customize (or regulate) your heat/spice level.) As a vegetarian they - offer probably the most options in the area. But also have so many other dishes for non-vegetarians.  A great brunch as well and fast for those without a lot of time for lunch.

data.title: Absolutely fantastic
data.text: Go to the buffet during the week.  Food is superb and the owner is a pleasure.  Tandoori chicken is to die for.  Not always out but ask for mint chutney. Best in the world.  Go home with a samosa to warm up at dinner

data.title: Spice-A-Riffic
data.text: As a fan of Indian Cuisine, I made a point to stop in for the Lamb Vindaloo...and was not disappointed. The portions were very generous and the food was excellent. Usually when I have something spicy I am left wanting it hotter, but had no complaints with this dish. The heat level was excellent and the flavor was just as good. My coworker got the Chicken Curry and was just as happy. The only drawback is that it is a small place off a side road, but if you like quant dining it may be just right for you.

data.title: Better than before
data.text:
This Indian food place used to be located on Jay Street, opposite City Hall, in a cramped, dingy storefront.
They moved to an out-of-the-way place on Clinton Street, just off the main drag, State Street.
My wife and I stopped by to try it out for a quick meal, before going to Proctor's Theater for a concert.
A few other customers were there for their early dinner. Before we left, more people came, so this business in not unknown. In fact, they have a lively luncheon during the week, being so close to the business district.
I enjoyed the vegetable meal, and my wife liked the chicken; spicy, but not too much.
Of course, we loved the mango lassi -- it soothes the spiciness of the main dish.
The service was prompt, and the chef and the cook both visited us to see how we liked their dishes. Their friendliness is similar to that found at Tara Kitchen -- no surprise: it's all in the family!
We will add this to our list of good places to eat in downtown Schenectady.

data.title: Excellent Indian Food
data.text: Small, cozy place.  Great for take out.  Food served hot and very flavorful. Offers vegan and gluten free options.  I enjoy the chicken and spinach with Indian cheese. Used to be located across from City Hall until fatal fire forced the move a few blocks away.

data.title: Less than mediocre!
data.text: If you've never had Indian food then don't let this be you first experience. I had the lunch buffet ($9).  There were a few choice but there's not much.  Just the standard options.  Pretty bland and not as much flavorful spice that usually associated with Indian cuisine. I the the salad dressing was that orange colored  French dressing of all things.  Most things were cold and the naan was a bit soggy from sitting in the buffet pan. Not so clean.  Service next to non-existent. Not really recommended.

data.title: good Indian food
data.text:
We love eating at Taj Mahal. We have ordered takeout from them in the past, but this was our first time sitting down at the restaurant (and in this newer location). 

Service was just okay that night. The place had every table packed because of another event going on there, so I think they were just slightly overwhelmed. The food, on the other hand, was wonderful. I ordered my favorite Chicken Tikka Masala. It's so delicious. I enjoyed having some of the naan alongside it that we ordered. My husband tried a shrimp dish and raved about it while eating it and even afterwards. 

Prices are on the more expensive side, but you won't leave hungry and the food is great.

data.title: Authentic & Reliably Good !
data.text: This family run eatery recently relocated to Clinton St in Schenectady, a few doors down from the SEFCU on State St.  The food and service remain very good and the pricing is quite reasonable.  Great weekday lunch buffet !    The owner is always on hand and don't be surprised if he brings out some small specialty "on the house"  which I have witnessed aa well as experienced.

data.title: Best Indian in the area
data.text: It is the only Indian in the area. I had a craving for Indian food. I used to have it all the time in the U.K. but since moving to the US, there aren't to many about. We had a vindaloo, tikka masala, peshawari naan and rice. I also asked for onion pakora's which weren't on the menu, but the made them specially. The food was pretty good, not the best I've ever had. The naan didn't seem all that fresh, and I would have preferred more lamb in my vindaloo instead of adding potatoes (it isn't meant to have potatoes in it). But we will be back, mainly due to the lack of alternatives.

data.title: Not a place for authentic Indian food !!
data.text:
Very very poor...
Poor service...bad ambiance...and very bad food !!
May be being only one reason...Only one indian restaurent in Schencatday...no other reason one can visit. !! Better spend some time and go to Karavalli in Lathem !! Prices also too expensive !!

data.title: Good Indian Food at reasonable price
data.text: Reasonably priced good Indian food in comparison to other Indian joints. They use less oil in their cooking and I find that to be good. For the price this place is good.

data.title: GREAT, GREAT, GREAT!
data.text: Everything about this resturant is GREAT! I come to eat here on all my work breaks and I've always brought company with me. The food is absolutely OUTSTANDING & the customer service is GREAT. The people that work here are always in a great mood. A few of my most favorite dishes are The Chicken Sheek Kabab & The Mixed Tandoori.

data.title: Best Indian Food in Schenectady
data.text: A family restaurant that does all the little things right.  They even grind their own spices!  The lunch buffet is a great deal as well.

data.title: On the gloppy side
data.text:
It's a pleasant low-key place with red-plaid plastic tablecloths.  It occupies two storefronts, so you can sit in one room or the other.  Beer is not served.  When I was there, a Bollywood movie was playing on a large screen for those inclined to watch, and the clientele was happy and well-behaved.  The staff were cognizant and helpful.  

The lamb biryani was made with yogurt sticking the rice to the bits of onion, taking the role of mayonnaise, as it were.  It reminded me a little bit of buttery Rice-a-roni with chunks of lamb embedded.  (It did not resemble the colorful, flaky biryani pictured on the restaurant's website.)  The lamb itself was plentiful and done perfectly, easy on the fork, no gristle.  

The saag paneer (spinach and cheese cubes) was a thick brown creamy soup (reminiscent of curried golden cream-of-mushroom) with spinach.  Rice was served with it.  

The kheema naan (bread stuffed with ground chicken!) was well made and very tasty.
